div.p: I arrived here Thursday night and an half past 9 Friday went up to Mr. Yeatmans office where the first person I saw was Sid Dummond who is a clerk in the office and who knew me at once and introduce me to Mr Yeatman who invited me inside of the rail and I sat there noticing the manner of doing business for untill half past 4 without an opportunity of speaking a work to Mr. Y. who was constantly employed with a crowd wanting this turns until that time when the office closed and he had a short time to speak to me but as I knew he had had no dinner I did not detain him there but want to see him again in the evening - he offered me the position of Local agent at LaGrange place about 18 miles from this with $4 per day pay - he says the country about there is very pleasant and I might ilke it so well as to make it a permanent home that he could give me a place

in turn at $3 per day. I told him I would rather go to LaGrange and tomorrow I go into his office to begin my duties, there will be proabably some days before I go out, as from some cause no one is allowed to go out of town into the country - the pay in on the first of every month so that none is due untill January but if you do not get the money from Kildebrant let me know and I will try and get some for you I went to chruch this morning and hear a good serman from Dr. White but there was no music tho the organ was use to pitch the tune and there was a good chair the church is also draped with black The town is much larger and prettier than I thought and the yards full of Magnolia, Crape Myrtle, Cape Jesamine and Cedar and many other familiar shrubs and the roses still red with their green leaves and fire is of but little rest there was none in church nor are there any stiris I had to stop one day at a hotel and can not yet find a boarding house several on which I called are full but am giving out the afternoon to see if I can find one as the expense of the hotel per day is nearly equal to my pay

I remained three house in Bloomington on my way and finding Fuller as the supot he directs me to Hubbards which I found easily and out there until 4 oclk and got supper which Mr Hubbard said he always had early another girls came home hungry at that hour they all got home before I left and are looking well. may much better than I ever expected to be here they are all at school and Amalia as the normal Ella & May at the High school which is not far from the house The place is much larger that I thought and is hilly and wooded and really a very pretty town much prettier than Joliet and I do wish you were there. the schools bring up good I got onto the Sleeping can at Centralia and the thing shook so that I thought my back would break on that I had taken a bad cold there was a fine boat waiting for the train at Cairo and as son as we got on board we left the fan to Memphis - $10 from Joliet to Cairo - 11.10, we found when we got to Hickman thirty mules from Cairo that 100 Guerailla had been in town the day before and taken horses and broken open stores and taken hats, shoes & we stopped

at Hickman about 8 hours taking in pight and lay an anchor about 6 hours in the night which prevented our getting in at the usual hour hit the boat was comfortable tho very full and the weather exacnable Mr Yeatman asked after Hatty - I had formed an idea that he was tall and thin when he is short and fat with a bald head and florid compexion - tho very busy I do miss you all so much that I expect to be home sick in as very short time and I do not know how long it may be before I kiss you all so kiss one another for me and remmber in your prayers as I do you all give my boy extra kisses every body says that money is to be made her eand I shall try and come in fence than my room is so dark that I can scarsely see to write.
